data.title: Github markdown for the world
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I expect the syntax highlighter either to ignore the text, to let the user choose a language or make a smart decision. Right now, if I try to edit a text in Spanish I get this (they are all valid words in Spanish):

![odd](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2801252/22533843/a58fa20c-e8f0-11e6-8851-8b82bfda70de.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new document and use "Github Markdown" syntax highlighting.
2. Write some text in Spanish and see how Atom highlights valid words as wrong.
3. Doubt your skills in your native language. Start to doubt everything you believe is true. Conclude that it's probably not me and I should ask for help in Atom's Github.

**Expected behavior:** there are many options that would be better:
- No syntax highlighting. English is just one more language and it wouldn't be reasonable to expect that people around the world only write text in English.
- Make a smart choice. I am sure there are many evaluation techniques to find out the current language, and the language-checker could be based on this. [Example of package](https://github.com/FGRibreau/node-language-detect). However, this would have to be complemented with.
- Allow the user to choose a language. It could be a sub-menu in the bottom-right next to the syntax highlight, but that would probably require a big overhaul. I am **not** asking to remove UTF-8, please don't change that as it's the best from JS world (previous PHP developer here).

**Actual behavior:** forces you to write in English if you don't want to be overwhelmed with red warnings.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
OS: Ubuntu 16.04

## Notes

Japanese language is correctly(?) ignored:

![jap](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2801252/22534228/e850ae9a-e8f2-11e6-8466-eb3a1f054dfd.png)

data.title: Normalize disk drive letter in path on Windows
data.body:
### Description of the Change

Currently atom creates two buffers for the same file if passed paths use difference case for disk drive letter, e.g. `d:\file.txt` and `D:\file.txt`

This change ensures that the absolute path always has disk drive letter in uppercase. 

### Alternate Designs

The other place where this fix could be applied is [findBufferForPath](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/project.coffee#L331) function. However the used function [resolvePath](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/project.coffee#L229) already has some path normalization code, so I think this is the best fit.

Actually Windows interpreters `file.txt` and `File.txt` as the same file. Maybe it makes sense to extend this patch and make Atom to do the same on this operation system, but I'm not sure because it can be file system specific. Any suggestions are welcome!

### Why Should This Be In Core?

I believe the current behavior of the editor is wrong for Windows users, so it makes no sense to create a plugin to fix that.

### Benefits

The main benefit I would like to get is the ability to click on parsed backtrace in my terminal emulation app (ConEmu). Right now it works, but atom opens second buffer for the same file because it doesn't normalize disk drive letter.

### Possible Drawbacks

The possible drawback is some broken tests, but I've checked that and it seems everything works.

### Applicable Issues

Here is the related issue #8221. It's not exactly about my problem, but it's very near.

data.title: 100% CPU on startup with opened files from $HOME folder (electron compile-cache.js, Linux)
data.body:
Hallo,
i get 100% CPU (one core) when opening files from $HOME folder (like .xinitrc). This does not happen when i copy the file to a subfolder (like $HOME/myfolder). I already deleted $HOME/.atom and $HOME/.config/Atom folders to start from scratch but without success. 
This also affects next empty Atom start (hogs CPU if the last opened file was from $HOME folder). It somehow remembers the last file (or path) even though its not opened.

Arch Linux, xfce, Atom 1.13

[![pic](http://abload.de/thumb/atm9zrpl.png)](http://abload.de/img/atm9zrpl.png)

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

2. ...

**Atom Version**: 2.2.1
**Electron Version**: 1.3.6
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.6
**Thrown From**: Atom Core


### Stack Trace

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined

```
At /Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1306

TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
    at TerminalWrapper.Terminal.refresh (/Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1306:18)
    at TerminalWrapper.Terminal._cursorBlink (/Applications/Learn IDE.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/learn-term.js/src/term.js:1422:8)
```

data.title: Atom detects es5 as 'Javascript with JSX'
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Simple Javascript files (es5) are auto-detected as `Javascript with JSX` rendering `linter-jshint` useless as it works when syntax is detected as `Javascript` only.

### Versions

```
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.6.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: atom do not reload file on sshfs when modified by external program
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

atom does not reload a file which is modified by an external program when the file is on a folder mounter by sshfs. This is very common with command like `svn up`, which means that you are overwriting all the changes made by other contributors.

I don't know if there are packages which does this, but I think this should be the default behaviour of any editor, at least atom should warn you.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. sshfs remote_host:remote_path localpath
2. atom localpath/myfile
3. cd localpath/myfile
4. svn up

**Expected behavior:** 

atom should reload the file after svn up

### Versions
Atom    : 1.12.7
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

emacs does

data.title: atom-environment.js is error when starting Atom via xrdp
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I using atom on linux mint OS via xrdp.

atom-environment.js is error when atom starting:
```log
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'addWarning' of undefined
 /usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/atom-environment.js:335 
```
but after, that I can use atom without problems.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. install atom
2. run it

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Developper Tool open in atom and show the error message.
![starting-error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2116356/22451320/f2e2cb24-e7b0-11e6-9f77-28523e0f51a2.png)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

```console
$ apm -v
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

OS : Linux Mint 18 MATE 64bit
xrdp : 0.6.1
vnc : TigerVNC 1.7.80

### Additional Information

Error does not occur with..

* do not use xrdp
* or super user command (via xrdp ok)
```console
$ su atom
```

data.title: notification.onDidDisplay()'s cb is never called
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Notification.onDidDisplay() is a publically documented API and does not work. A quick search through the main repo shows that the private [notification.setDisplayed()](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/notification.coffee#L76) is never called, so the 'did-display' event is never fired. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. 
```js
// works
atom.notifications.addInfo("hey!",{dismissable: true})
  .onDidDismiss(() => {console.log("dismissed")});

// does not work
atom.notifications.addInfo("hey!",{dismissable: true})
  .onDidDisplay(() => {console.log("displayed!")});
```
### Versions
1.13.1 x64 Ubuntu 16.04

data.title: pass through line count options
data.body:
This is in support of atom/find-and-replace#847.

### Requirements

* atom/find-and-replace#847
* atom/scandal#41
* atom/text-buffer#195

### Description of the Change

Add two additional optional options to `workspace.scan` (namely `lineCountBefore` and `lineCountAfter`) and pass them along to the `scan-handler` and from there to the `PassSearcher`.

### Alternate Designs

I am not aware of an alternative approach.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Since the modified API for searching is part of the core it needs to be extended to support the use case described in atom/find-and-replace#190. If the `find-and-replace` package could handle this without requiring modifications to the core that would be great but with the current API being provided by the core I don't think this is possible.

### Benefits

It implements the long desired feature described in atom/find-and-replace#190.

### Possible Drawbacks

The additional optional argument shouldn't result in any backward compatibility problem as far as I can tell.

### Applicable Issues / Remaining Todos

* ~~In the current state when the search results list a file which is not opened yet and you click on the result the match is being updated and looses the context information. This is due to the fact that the search is being repeated in the buffer (instead of using `scandal` through the workspace API. In order to address this the `TextBuffer.scan` needs to be extended to support the same new options as in the referenced `scandal` ticket. Therefore I have prefixed the title with `[WIP]` for now.~~ This has been address with the PR to the `text-buffer` package.

* Add test coverage / update existing specs as soon as there is a consensus on the selected approach and the feature works.

data.title: Wrong .gitignore path on Windows
data.body:
### Description
When I save .gitignore file I take a fail . 

!!!! I have permissions to the file. The bug is by wrong path.

```
Unable to save file 'C:\.\work\src\github.com\goatcms\goatcms.gitignore'
EPERM: operation not permitted, open 'C:\...\work\src\github.com\goatcms\goatcms\.gitignore'
```

Path is:
C:\\.\work\src\github.com\goatcms\goatcms.gitignore
and it should be:
C:\\...\work\src\github.com\goatcms\goatcms\.gitignore
**Plase don't close without check.** 

![error-atom-gitignore](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1093166/22395869/f0839466-e54a-11e6-812b-b7640c4a6c21.png)


[Description of the issue]

### Steps to Reproduce

1. create .gitignore file
2. open it in atom
3. save

**Expected behavior:** 
save file (without errors)

**Actual behavior:** 
it is fail

**Reproduces how often:**
Always

### Versions
Windows 10
atom 1.13.1 ia32

Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python
git 2.11.0.windows.3
visual studio

data.title: Some part of selected lines seen unselected if dragged vertically after selecting text
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Setup
OS : ubuntu 16.04
GPU : Intel Haswell
### Description

[Description of the issue]
Some section of the selected lines , seen unselected if scrolled Vertically back and forth.
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a big file [HTML File in my case]
2. Select some Lines [~10 Lines]
3. Using Track pad scroll it vertically.
4. Observe Some section won't seen selected. [Screenshot attached]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
All lines should be selected either scrolled back and forth vertically

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Some part of lines gets unslected.
**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
It reproduce 10 out of 9 time on vertically scrolling after selecting lines
### Versions

# apm --version
apm  1.12.9
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

# atom --version
Atom    : 1.12.1
Electron: 1.3.6
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.3.0

Please let me know if any other information needed.
Also i would feel great if i can be in some part of contribution. :)

data.title: Valid code highlight breaks on long conditional (ternary) operator and in many familiar
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
Highlighting of the valid code breaks
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Insert this code to your _.php_ files
```PHP
<?
/**
 *
 * Extract unique values ( from multidimensional array ) by using specific keys
 * @return array
 *
 */
function array_multi_unique_values($input_array, $v1, $v2 = false, $v3 = false, $v4 = false, $v5 = false, $v6 = false, $v7 = false, $v8 = false)
{
    if (is_array($input_array)) {
        $output_array = [];
        foreach ($input_array as $array) {
            $output_array[] = $array[$v1] . (!empty($array[$v2]) ? ', ' . $array[$v2] : false) . (!empty($array[$v3]) ? ', ' . $array[$v3] : false) . (!empty($array[$v4]) ? ', ' . $array[$v4] : false) . (!empty($array[$v5]) ? ', ' . $array[$v5] : false) . (!empty($array[$v6]) ? ', ' . $array[$v6] : false) . (!empty($array[$v7]) ? ', ' . $array[$v7] : false) . (!empty($array[$v8]) ? ', ' . $array[$v8] : false);
        }
        return array_unique($output_array);
    } else {
        return false;
    }
}
```
2. Set file type to PHP if necessary

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Code being highlighted the same way us on GitHub for example.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
It doesn't, here is the example in the screenshot:
![screenshot from 2017-01-28 21-48-22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4426533/22399025/75032a5e-e5a4-11e6-8c70-9a3bde34e60c.png)


**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
All the time

### Versions
Atom Editor v1.13.1

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

### Additional Information
Linux Fedora 25

data.title: Key combination doesn't show up in the menu -> `alt-shift-n`
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I have created a new package [toggle-mode-modules](https://atom.io/packages/toggle-node-modules) and tried to use the following as a default keymap, but it does NOT appear when selecting `Packages -> Toggle Node Modules -> Toggle`

I have since changed the default to `ctrl-shift-t` which now works...

```
'.platform-linux atom-workspace, .platform-win32 atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': 'toggle-node-modules:toggle'

'.platform-darwin atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': 'toggle-node-modules:toggle'
``` 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. This can be replicated by trying to create a new entry in `keymap.cson`

```
'.platform-darwin atom-workspace':
  'shift-ctrl-t': **'toggle-node-modules:toggle'
```

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I expected the defined keymap to appear in `Packages -> Toggle Node Modules -> Toggle`

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

No menu keyboard equivalent appears

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100%

### Versions

Atom    : 1.13.1
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information

Had discussion on Slack channel with @BinaryMuse and @lee-dohm who requested I create this ticket

data.title: Odd behaviour as editor to a rebase
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Until recently[1], using `atom` as my `VISUAL` editor during an interactive rebase would open the `git-rebase-todo` temporary file in a new tab in Atom and allow me to perform changes before saving and closing.

Now, instead of waiting, it deletes each line in the file one by one, and closes it.  Performing commits this way are unchanged.

Using `atom --wait` resolves the issue but at the cost of startup time as it opens a new window rather than a new tab.

Using `atom --safe` has no effect.

`atom --clear-window-state` had no effect.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set `atom` as your `VISUAL`.
2. Perform a `git rebase -i` with or without `--root`.

**Expected behavior:**

A new tab opens in the same project as the directory I'm in containing `git-rebase-todo` and takes action only when I save and close the file.

**Actual behavior:**

`git rebase -i --root`
![rebase](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/109225/22371780/feadcb02-e490-11e6-83f0-b83adcc39a08.gif)

`git commit`
![commit](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/109225/22371894/dd6645ea-e491-11e6-8cd3-06f63d5b2ec2.gif)

**Reproduces how often:**

100% of time with an interactive rebase
0% of the time with a commit

### Versions
```
macOS Sierra 10.12.2 (16C67)
```

```
Atom    : 1.13.1 (most recent at time of writing)
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

```
apm  1.14.1
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0
```

### Additional Information

Using `atom --wait` as my `VISUAL` does not have the same problem, however it is less than ideal because opening a new window rather than a new tab is subject to atom's relatively slow startup time.

[1] I don't know how recently this started happening as it has been a while since I did an interactive rebase.

data.title: Autocomplete duplication
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:

### Description

I've just loaded the last beta portable version for the first Atom try. The autocompletion test causes unexpected behavior: the object name is doubled before the property (the same in the safe mode / with factory defaults). Sorry, if I get something wrong.

### Steps to Reproduce
![autocomplete](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10393198/22356694/0679d81c-e43c-11e6-9e36-f71d5703816d.gif)

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
```js
console.log();
```

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
```js
console.console.log();
```

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
Persistently.

### Versions
Atom    : 1.14.0-beta3 (atom-x64-windows.zip)
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS: Windows 7 x64

I'm currently on MacOSX 10.11.6. When I run `sudo script/build` it gives the following:

```

                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ^  ~~~~~~~~~~~~
1 warning generated.
../deps/libgit2/deps/zlib/inflate.c:1507:61: warning: shifting a negative signed value is undefined [-Wshift-negative-value]
    if (strm == Z_NULL || strm->state == Z_NULL) return -1L << 16;
```

data.title: Lint JavaScript specs
data.body:
### Requirements

* Filling out the template is required. Any pull request that does not include enough information to be reviewed in a timely manner may be closed at the maintainers' discretion.
* All new code requires tests to ensure against regressions

### Description of the Change

Lints specs written in JS.

### Alternate Designs

None.

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Because everything else gets linted in core?

### Benefits

Better code quality.

### Possible Drawbacks

None.

### Applicable Issues

None.

data.title: Python autocomplete for gi.repository module
data.body:
I'd really love to use Atom for my Python development needs, but I cannot get autocompletion to work for PyGObject module. I use Arch Linux and I have pygobject-devel packages installed.

On the Atom side I have autocomplete-python and python-tools plugins. PyGObject itself works fine, since I can perfectly fine run any gui program.

I experience no problems with django autocomplete which was installed the same way (python-django from Arch repo) so I guess it's some problem with atom.
